Class ec.ezlib.prim.E 

java.lang.Object
   |
   +----ec.ezlib.prim.E
public class E
extends Object
This class is most of the normal application programmer's API to the EZLib functionality. In particular, the send methods below are what E's "<-" turn into.

NOTE! All the methods of this class trust their callers to 1) only provide interned strings as verbs, and 2) not modify an args array after passing it in. Btw, all source code literal strings are automatically intern()ed. EZLib itself will never modify a passed-in args array.

call(Object, Resolver, String, Object[])
Do the described event now, with outcome reported to optResolver.
call(Object, String, Object[])
Do the described event now, with outcome returned (ie, a result) or thrown ("abrupt termination" in JLS terminology).
callOnly(Object, String, Object[])
Do the described event now, with outcome ignored.
optProblem(Object)
If BROKEN, this returns the reason.
resolution(Object)
User-means of channel shortening.
send(Object, String)
send(Object, String, Object)
send(Object, String, Object, Object)
send(Object, String, Object, Object, Object)
sendAll(Object, Resolver, String, Object[])
Ensure 'rec' will be invoked in the way described, by queueing it onto the current run queue.
sendAll(Object, String, Object[])
Queue the described delivery.
sendAllOnly(Object, String, Object[])
Like sendAll(rec, verb, args), except that "Only" means we don't care about the result (including whether it succeeded), as is appropriate for event notifications.

sendOnly(Object, String, Object)

Should this reference become BROKEN (or already be BROKEN), call the brokenNoticer's run() method with this reference.
whenKept(Object, Object)

 public static Object call(Object rec,
                           String verb,
                           Object args[]) throws Exception, Ejection
Do the described event now, with outcome returned (ie, a result) or thrown ("abrupt termination" in JLS terminology).

                         Resolver optResolver,
                         String verb,
                         Object args[])
Do the described event now, with outcome reported to optResolver.

callOnly 
 public static void callOnly(Object rec,
                             String verb,
                             Object args[])
Do the described event now, with outcome ignored.

sendAll 
 public static Object sendAll(Object rec,
                              String verb,
                              Object args[])
Queue the described delivery. Rather than providing an explicit Resolver as input argument, this method returns a Promise that represents the outcome. When the actual outcome is reported to the internally generated Resolver, the Promise will reflect that outcome.

This should only synchronously throw an exception if invoked while there's no current Runner.

sendAllOnly 
 public static void sendAllOnly(Object rec,
                                String verb,
                                Object args[])
Like sendAll(rec, verb, args), except that "Only" means we don't care about the result (including whether it succeeded), as is appropriate for event notifications.

sendAll 
 public static void sendAll(Object rec,
                            Resolver optResolver,
                            String verb,
                            Object args[])
Ensure 'rec' will be invoked in the way described, by queueing it onto the current run queue. These will be serviced in an order that preserves poE semantics.

'resolver' must be UNRESOLVED. When sendAll() returns, 'resolver' will no longer be UNRESOLVED (i.e., sendAll() forward()s 'resolver')

toss 
 public static void toss(Throwable t) throws Exception, Ejection
state 
 public static String state(Object obj)
One of "DEFERRED", "KEPT", or "BROKEN", as an interned string. (May not be "UNRESOLVED" or "FORWARDED".)

A DEFERRED reference is unreliably invokable by E.send() (ie, the message may not get delivered to the designated recipient).

A KEPT reference is reliably invokable by E.send() and E.call() and possibly directly by Java "." (ie, the object is synchronously callable and therefore within the same concurrency and atomic failure unit).

A BROKEN reference is one that fails to designate an object. It has an associated Throwable that explains what problem() resulted in this condition.

A Sendable may be in any of these three states. A non-Sendable is equivalent to a KEPT Sendable. A DEFERRED Sendable may become KEPT or BROKEN. A KEPT Sendable must forever remain KEPT, and a BROKEN Sendable must forever remain BROKEN.

resolution 
 public static Object resolution(Object obj)
User-means of channel shortening.

If "DEFERRED", this returns itself (or a Sendable equivalent to itself but possibly more efficient).

If "KEPT", this returns a non-Sendable or a KEPT Sendable equivalent to itself. The resolution of a KEPT reference may be callable by both java dot and E.call(), even if the original was only callable by E.call(). Non-Sendables return themselves.

If "BROKEN", this throws a NestedException containing the problem. XXX Perhaps we should change this case to return self instead.

optProblem 
 public static Throwable optProblem(Object obj)
If BROKEN, this returns the reason. Otherwise null. Therefore, non-Sendables always return null.

whenKept 
 public static void whenKept(Object obj,
                             Object keptNoticer)
Should this reference become KEPT (or already be KEPT), send to the keptNoticer's run() method with this reference. If you want instead to be notified when this reference comes to designate an object, even if it stays DEFERRED (as would happen remotely), do instead a

E.sendOnly(obj, "ping", pongNoticer);

This is the closest analog to the old ewhen mechanism. Use sendOnly() for ping, since interest in the reference becoming broken is expressable using E.whenBroken().)

See Also:
ping
whenBroken 
 public static void whenBroken(Object obj,
                               Object brokenNoticer)
Should this reference become BROKEN (or already be BROKEN), call the brokenNoticer's run() method with this reference.
